elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig3">

<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Referring to structure <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, (a–c) pytac A ‘Blue’, pytac B ‘black’, pytac C ‘brown’, Co1 ‘green’, and Co2 ‘purple’. (d) Pytac C connecting the 1D chains.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr3"></ce:link>

elements.clean_text:
Abstract
Three new coordination polymers containing 2-(4-pyridyl)thiazole-4-carboxylate (pytac) with cobalt, vanadium oxide, or cadmium iodide have been synthesized solvothermally, isolated, and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction and powder X-ray diffraction. [Co3(pytac)6](H2O)8 (1), which crystallizes in the space group C2/c (a
=24.1418(8)Å, b
=17.5088(6)Å, and c
=14.4562(5)Å, β =96.0390(10)°), has 1D hexameric water channels that constitute a 14.4% of the unit cell volume. Co3(pytac)2(H2O)4V4O12 (2), which crystallizes in the space group 

P

1
¯


 (a
=8.6591(5)Å, b
=9.0044(5)Å, and c
=10.6495(6)Å, α
=67.1160(10)°, β
=82.6880(10)°, and γ
=83.9880(10)°), is an extension of the former in that it contains Co(H2O)4V4O12 in addition to the Co-only 2D layers. [CdI(pytac)(H2O)]·H2O (3), which also crystallizes in the space group 

P

1
¯


 (a
=8.2376(4)Å, b
=8.4859(4)Å, and c
=11.1261(5)Å, α=68.2020(10)°, β
=77.5610(10)°, and γ
=69.1230(10)°), exhibits structural characteristics similar to 2, in that both contain 1D chains where the pytac ligand simultaneously engages in three different coordination modes: chelating, single bond coordination, and μ-2 bridging between two metal centers via carboxylate oxygen atoms.

elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract





A unique mixed-metal 3D coordination polymer composed of interlinked layers of 1D strands that are segregated into metal–organic and inorganic components.
Introduction
In the field of inorganic–organic framework materials, ligands that can engage in multiple coordination modes have yielded many interesting structure types . For example, the pyrazinecarboxylate ligand (pca) and its substituted derivatives have proven to be extremely versatile for the synthesis of novel coordination framework structures due to their ability to engage simultaneously in several different coordination modes . This coordination ability has enabled these ligands to be used for the formation of stable metal-containing building blocks that can further coordinate to other metal centers . This approach has resulted in the synthesis of a very large number of mixed-metal coordination polymers, many of which exhibit complex channel-containing 3D structures. As the channel size was limited by the short terminal N–N separation of the pyrazinecarboxylate ligand, a longer ligand, 4-(pyridin-4-yl)pyridine-2-carboxylate (ppca), was synthesized in order to obtain similar structures with larger cavities (
) . Use of this ligand, in one case, led to the synthesis of a unique coordination polymer capable of undergoing dynamic structural changes upon addition/removal of uncoordinated and coordinated water molecules .

elements.content:
<ce:figure>
<ce:link locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>

<ce:para view="all">These results prompted us to choose structurally similar ligands that could engage in multiple, simultaneous coordination modes and to use such ligands in the assembly of novel coordination polymers. We identified 2-(4-pyridyl)thiazole-4-carboxate (pytac) (<ce:float-anchor refid="sch2"></ce:float-anchor>
) as one ligand of suitable length and have begun to use it in the preparation of new coordination frameworks . This ligand is similar to pca and ppca in that there exists a terminal and a chelating nitrogen coordination site that can be used for coordinating to metal centers. However, while in the case of pca and ppca the coordination sites are in a linear arrangement with respect to each other, in the case of pytac, the chelating nitrogen is no longer exactly opposite the terminal nitrogen, but rather is oriented approximately perpendicular to it. This spatial arrangement of the nitrogens enables the ligand to function as a ‘bent’ spacer . The ‘bent’ orientation of the ligand's N-donor atoms, as well as the presence of an additional Lewis base site in the form of a ring-sulfur atom, lead us to believe that the use of this ligand could yield equally, if not more, diverse structures compared to those containing the pca or ppca ligands. In this paper we report on our continued results with the use of this ligand that has yielded three new structures: two single-metal coordination polymers <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, and a mixed-metal coordination polymer <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. Their syntheses and structures are detailed within.</ce:para>

However, while in the case of pca and ppca the coordination sites are in a linear arrangement with respect to each other, in the case of pytac, the chelating nitrogen is no longer exactly opposite the terminal nitrogen, but rather is oriented approximately perpendicular to it. This spatial arrangement of the nitrogens enables the ligand to function as a ‘bent’ spacer . The ‘bent’ orientation of the ligand's N-donor atoms, as well as the presence of an additional Lewis base site in the form of a ring-sulfur atom, lead us to believe that the use of this ligand could yield equally, if not more, diverse structures compared to those containing the pca or ppca ligands. In this paper we report on our continued results with the use of this ligand that has yielded three new structures: two single-metal coordination polymers 1 and 3, and a mixed-metal coordination polymer 2. elements.content: <ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Materials and methods</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">2-(4-Pyridyl)thiazole-4-carboxylic acid or ‘pytac’ was purchased from Sigma–Aldrich and used without further purification. Cobalt nitrate, cadmium iodide, and ammonium vanadate were all purchased from Fisher and used without further purification. Ethanol (AAPER, 100%) was used as received. The solvent system in all reactions was ethanol/water (1/1) or just water.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental
Materials and methods
2-(4-Pyridyl)thiazole-4-carboxylic acid or ‘pytac’ was purchased from Sigma–Aldrich and used without further purification. Cobalt nitrate, cadmium iodide, and ammonium vanadate were all purchased from Fisher and used without further purification. Ethanol (AAPER, 100%) was used as received. The solvent system in all reactions was ethanol/water (1/1) or just water.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Synthesis</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">In a typical procedure pytac (0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), cobalt nitrate or cadmium iodide (0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), and ammonium vanadate (0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), were placed in a 23<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL Teflon-lined autoclave with 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL water. The autoclave was subsequently sealed and heated to 130<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C at 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/min and held at that temperature for 72<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. At the end of this period, the autoclave was cooled to 80<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C at 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/min and held at that temperature for 12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h before cooling to room temperature at the same rate. Cobalt nitrate and pytac were utilized for the synthesis of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. An irregular orange crystal fragment was cleaved from a multi-crystalline mass and used for the single-crystal X-ray analysis. Cobalt nitrate, ammonium vanadate, and pytac were used in the synthesis of complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. An irregular, orange-red crystal was used for the single-crystal X-ray analysis. Cadmium iodide and pytac were used to synthesize complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. A yellow bar-shaped crystal was used for the single-crystal X-ray analysis.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis
In a typical procedure pytac (0.5mmol), cobalt nitrate or cadmium iodide (0.5mmol), and ammonium vanadate (0.5mmol), were placed in a 23mL Teflon-lined autoclave with 10mL water. The autoclave was subsequently sealed and heated to 130°C at 1°C/min and held at that temperature for 72h. At the end of this period, the autoclave was cooled to 80°C at 0.1°C/min and held at that temperature for 12h before cooling to room temperature at the same rate. Cobalt nitrate and pytac were utilized for the synthesis of complex 1. An irregular orange crystal fragment was cleaved from a multi-crystalline mass and used for the single-crystal X-ray analysis. Cobalt nitrate, ammonium vanadate, and pytac were used in the synthesis of complex 2. An irregular, orange-red crystal was used for the single-crystal X-ray analysis. Cadmium iodide and pytac were used to synthesize complex 3. A yellow bar-shaped crystal was used for the single-crystal X-ray analysis.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>X-ray crystallography</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Powder X-ray diffraction measurements were performed on a Rigaku D/max 2100 diffractometer (Cu Kα radiation, <ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>1.5418<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). For single-crystal diffraction measurements X-ray intensity data were measured at 150(1) or 293(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD-based diffractometer (Mo Kα radiation, <ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). Raw data frame integration and Lp corrections were performed with SAINT+. Analysis of the data showed negligible crystal decay during collection. Direct methods structure solution, difference Fourier calculations and full-matrix least-squares refinement against <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> were performed with SHELXTL . Data from structures <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were corrected for absorption effects with SADABS . Final unit cell parameters were determined by least-squares refinement of 7483 (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), 2988 (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), and 4742 (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) reflections with <ce:italic>I</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>><ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>5<ce:italic>σ</ce:italic>(<ce:italic>I</ce:italic>) from each data set.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography
Powder X-ray diffraction measurements were performed on a Rigaku D/max 2100 diffractometer (Cu Kα radiation, λ
=1.5418Å). For single-crystal diffraction measurements X-ray intensity data were measured at 150(1) or 293(2)K on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD-based diffractometer (Mo Kα radiation, λ
=0.71073Å). Raw data frame integration and Lp corrections were performed with SAINT+. Analysis of the data showed negligible crystal decay during collection. Direct methods structure solution, difference Fourier calculations and full-matrix least-squares refinement against F
2 were performed with SHELXTL . Data from structures 1–3 were corrected for absorption effects with SADABS . Final unit cell parameters were determined by least-squares refinement of 7483 (1), 2988 (2), and 4742 (3) reflections with I
>5σ(I) from each data set.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In structure <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the asymmetric unit consists of two cobalt atoms, (one of which (Co2) lies on a two-fold axis of rotation), three independent pytac ligands and four independent water molecules. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. Hydrogen atoms bonded to carbon atoms were placed in geometrically idealized positions and included as riding atoms. The water hydrogens were located in difference maps. Their positional coordinates were refined with all O–H distances restrained to be approximately equal. The hydrogen atoms of oxygen O10 are disordered over two positions, H10A/H10B and H10A/H10C (H10A common to both). After determining reasonable positions for the half-occupied disordered hydrogens H10B and H10C, these atoms were treated as riding on the parent oxygen.</ce:para>

The water hydrogens were located in difference maps. Their positional coordinates were refined with all O–H distances restrained to be approximately equal. The hydrogen atoms of oxygen O10 are disordered over two positions, H10A/H10B and H10A/H10C (H10A common to both). After determining reasonable positions for the half-occupied disordered hydrogens H10B and H10C, these atoms were treated as riding on the parent oxygen.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In structure <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the asymmetric unit consists of two cobalt atoms, two vanadium atoms, one pytac ligand, six inorganic oxygen atoms that are part of a V<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf> ring, and two water molecules. Co2 lies on a crystallographic inversion center; all other atoms are on positions of general crystallographic symmetry. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. Hydrogen atoms bonded to carbon were placed in geometrically idealized positions and included as riding atoms. The water hydrogens were located in difference maps and refined with a common isotropic displacement parameter. The O–H distances were restrained to be approximately equal.</ce:para>

Co2 lies on a crystallographic inversion center; all other atoms are on positions of general crystallographic symmetry. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. Hydrogen atoms bonded to carbon were placed in geometrically idealized positions and included as riding atoms. The water hydrogens were located in difference maps and refined with a common isotropic displacement parameter. The O–H distances were restrained to be approximately equal.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In structure <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, the asymmetric unit consists of one complete formula unit. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. Hydrogen atoms bonded to carbon atoms were placed in geometrically idealized positions and included as riding atoms. The water hydrogens were located in difference maps and refined with a common isotropic displacement parameter. Their positions were refined freely.</ce:para>

elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion
Structure description
The reactions of the pytac ligand with cobalt nitrate, ammonium vanadate, or cadmium iodide under solvothermal conditions resulted in crystals of 1–3, whose structures were determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Structure 1 is a 3D structure that contains 1D hexameric water channels that constitute 14.4% of the unit cell volume. Structure 2 contains metal–organic 1D chains/layers that are connected to inorganic hydrogen-bonded 2D layers of Co(H2O)4V4O12. Structure 3 contains infinite 1D chains, similar to the metal–organic chains in 2, that hydrogen bond to neighboring chains, via uncoordinated water molecules. Crystal data, data collection parameters, and refinement statistics for 1–3 are listed in 
. Relevant interatomic distances and bond angles for 1–3 are listed in 

, respectively.

<ce:para view="all">For simplicity, each of the three crystallographically distinct pytac ligands and two crystallographically distinct Co centers have been color coded in <ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>

 as follows: pytac A ‘Blue’ (C1–C9, N1–N2, O1–O2, and S1); pytac B ‘black’ (C10–C18, N3–N4, O3–O4, and S2); pytac C ‘brown’ (C19–C7, N5–N6, O5–O6, and S3), Co1 ‘green’, and Co2 ‘purple’. Pytac A and B tether Co1 and Co2 into 1D chains in the [10−1] direction (a and b). Pytac A tethers each Co center by chelating (two oxygen atoms (O1 and O2) from the carboxylate group) to Co1 and coordinating to Co2 (pyridyl nitrogen atom (N2)). Pytac B tethers the two centers by chelating (nitrogen and oxygen atoms (N5 and O5)) to Co2 and coordinating (pyridyl nitrogen donor atom (N6) to Co1 (c). These 1D chains are connected to each other via pytac C (d).</ce:para>

The equatorial sites of all Co1 atoms are occupied by pytac nitrogen and oxygen donor atoms through three different interactions: chelating (Co(1)–N(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>2.159(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and Co(1)–O(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>2.125(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), coordination via the pyridyl nitrogen (Co(1)–N(2)#2<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>2.099(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), and an μ-2 interaction from the carboxylate oxygen atom (O1) which bridges the two Co1 centers (Co(1)–O(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>2.125(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and Co(1)–O(1)#1<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>2.128(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) (<ce:float-anchor refid="fig7"></ce:float-anchor>

Co2(pytac)2 repeat units make up the metal–organic strands that form 1D chains in the [001] direction. The two crystallographically distinct Co centers are linked by two (equivalent) pytac ligands. The equatorial sites of all Co1 atoms are occupied by pytac nitrogen and oxygen donor atoms through three different interactions: chelating (Co(1)–N(1)=2.159(3)Å and Co(1)–O(1)=2.125(2)Å), coordination via the pyridyl nitrogen (Co(1)–N(2)#2=2.099(3)Å), and an μ-2 interaction from the carboxylate oxygen atom (O1) which bridges the two Co1 centers (Co(1)–O(1)=2.125(2)Å and Co(1)–O(1)#1=2.128(2)Å) (
). The free carboxylate oxygen atom H-bonds (O2⋯H10B=1.952Å) to the inorganic layer (see below). The two axial sites of the Co1 centers are occupied by O3 and O7 (Co(1)–O(3)=2.051(2)Å and Co(1)–O(7)#1=2.043(2)Å), tethering the metal–organic chains to the adjacent inorganic layers.

The layers of inorganic 1D chains are composed of Co(H2O)4V4O12 units that extend along the [0−11] direction (
). These units contain the commonly observed V4O12 groups . (V(1)–O(3)=1.649(2)Å, V(1)–O(4)=1.657(2)Å, V(1)–O(6)#4=1.791(2)Å, V(1)–O(5)=1.798(2)Å, V(2)–O(8)=1.622(2)Å, V(2)–O(7)=1.659(2)Å, V(2)–O(5)=1.803(2)Å, and V(2)–O(6)=1.818(2)Å.), fused axially (through O4) to Co(H2O)4 units (Co(2)–O(4)#3=2.103(2)Å and Co(2)–O(4)=2.103(2)Å). All equatorial positions on the Co2 center are occupied by coordinated water molecules (Co(2)–O(10)#3=2.086(3)Å, Co(2)–O(10)=2.086(3)Å, Co(2)–O(9)=2.104(2)Å, and Co(2)–O(9)#3=2.105(2)Å). These 1D chains are H-bonded (2.048Å) to adjacent chains through H9–O8. In addition, intra-chain H-bonding (2.138Å) occurs between H10–O6 ().

The infinite 1D chains propagate in the [01−1] direction (

<ce:section-title>Powder X-ray diffraction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">While elemental analysis can provide feedback concerning the compositional content of a sample, powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) can provide, in addition, phase purity information, for example, to detect the presence of polymorphs. Hence, to characterize samples prepared by solvothermal methods, XRD data were collected and analyzed.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray diffraction
While elemental analysis can provide feedback concerning the compositional content of a sample, powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) can provide, in addition, phase purity information, for example, to detect the presence of polymorphs. Hence, to characterize samples prepared by solvothermal methods, XRD data were collected and analyzed.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Deep red block-crystals, identified as <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, are obtained from the solvothermal reaction of pytac, cobalt nitrate and ammonium vanadate. The composition and phase purity of the product was confirmed by overlaying the simulated X-ray diffraction pattern calculated from single-crystal X-ray diffraction data with the observed powder pattern of the product as shown in <ce:float-anchor refid="fig14"></ce:float-anchor>
.</ce:para>

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Ligand coordination modes</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The pytac ligand was chosen for its numerous coordination sites and for its potential ability to chelate to a metal center via the nitrogen and one oxygen from a proximal carboxylic acid group. Interestingly, in structure <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the ‘blue’ (one of the three crystallographically distinct ligands, ) pytac ligand did not engage in this chelating coordination mode involving the nitrogen and one carboxylate oxygen, instead chelated via two carboxylate oxygens. This coordination behavior was also observed with ZnF(pytac)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) . In both <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, on the other hand, all pytac ligands chelated via the ring nitrogen and the adjacent carboxylate oxygens, the typical coordination mode for the pca and ppca ligands we have studied previously. In addition, the oxygen atoms involved with chelation in both <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> simultaneously bridged a symmetry equivalent metal center (Co–Co<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>3.298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and Cd–Cd<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>3.771<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>)).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Ligand coordination modes
The pytac ligand was chosen for its numerous coordination sites and for its potential ability to chelate to a metal center via the nitrogen and one oxygen from a proximal carboxylic acid group. Interestingly, in structure 1, the ‘blue’ (one of the three crystallographically distinct ligands, ) pytac ligand did not engage in this chelating coordination mode involving the nitrogen and one carboxylate oxygen, instead chelated via two carboxylate oxygens. This coordination behavior was also observed with ZnF(pytac)(H2O) . In both 2 and 3, on the other hand, all pytac ligands chelated via the ring nitrogen and the adjacent carboxylate oxygens, the typical coordination mode for the pca and ppca ligands we have studied previously. In addition, the oxygen atoms involved with chelation in both 2 and 3 simultaneously bridged a symmetry equivalent metal center (Co–Co=3.298Å in 2 and Cd–Cd=3.771Å in 3)).

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Due to the many potential metal coordination sites, all three structures are 3D frameworks. Only in the structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, however, is the three-dimensionality a direct result of the ligand coordination sites. Structures <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> exhibit extensive and diverse H-bonding that leads to their three-dimensionality. Due to the diverse coordination modes, the pytac ligand, similar to the pca and ppca ligands, should be able to selectively bind to different metal centers using distinct donor sites. Work ongoing in our group is exploring this exciting ligand in the expectation of generating new 3D mixed-metal frameworks containing nickel/copper with vanadates and molybdates.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Due to the many potential metal coordination sites, all three structures are 3D frameworks. Only in the structure of 1, however, is the three-dimensionality a direct result of the ligand coordination sites. Structures 2 and 3 exhibit extensive and diverse H-bonding that leads to their three-dimensionality. Due to the diverse coordination modes, the pytac ligand, similar to the pca and ppca ligands, should be able to selectively bind to different metal centers using distinct donor sites. Work ongoing in our group is exploring this exciting ligand in the expectation of generating new 3D mixed-metal frameworks containing nickel/copper with vanadates and molybdates.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">We have successfully synthesized three novel coordination polymers using 2-(4-pyridyl)thiazole-4-carboxylate (pytac), cobalt, cadmium, and vanadium oxide. The structures of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> demonstrate the effectiveness of this asymmetric ligand's ability to generate new and diverse 3D coordination framework structures. Future work will explore the use of this ligand in the assembly of additional mixed-metal frameworks.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion
We have successfully synthesized three novel coordination polymers using 2-(4-pyridyl)thiazole-4-carboxylate (pytac), cobalt, cadmium, and vanadium oxide. The structures of 1–3 demonstrate the effectiveness of this asymmetric ligand's ability to generate new and diverse 3D coordination framework structures. Future work will explore the use of this ligand in the assembly of additional mixed-metal frameworks.

metadata.title: Synthesis, characterization, and crystal structures of novel single and mixed-metal framework materials assembled from 2-(4-pyridyl)thiazole-4-carboxylic acid with cobalt, cadmium, and vanadium oxide
